questions.question_text: Which command on a WAN Edge device displays the information about the colors present in the fabric that are learned from vSmart via OMP?

discussion.content: IP colour enacp

Which two WAN Edge devices should be deployed in a cloud? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
CD are correct

choices.B: between ge 0/2.101 of port-type service and ge 0/0 of port-type service
choices.D: between ge 0/2.101 of port-type transport and ge 0/0 of port-type transport
choices.A: between ge 0/2.101 of port-type transport and ge 0/0 of port-type service
choices.C: between ge 0/2.101 of port-type service and ge 0/0 of port-type transport

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D - Transport to Transport

Zdrobici is correct.

refer to Figure 7 in: 
https://www.networkacademy.io/ccie-enterprise/sdwan/connecting-to-the-wan-using-tloc-extension

All required configuration is shown in figure 7 above. Once the config is applied, we can see that vEdge-2’s ge0/0 is NOW A TRANSPORT interface and acts as a local TLOC marked with the “biz-internet” color.

C is correct
The primary function of tloc-extension is to extend the transport interface properties to a service interface. This means that after the configuration, ge0/2.101 can now use ge0/0's transport capabilities for overlay traffic. However, ge0/2.101 does not become a transport interface itself; it remains a service interface that can utilize the transport functions of ge0/0.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: D
D - in the device template TLOCs (extension) are configured in the transport.

Selected Answer: D

initially port type is SERVICE, after tloc-ext config is ADDED is becoming TRANSPORT.

so we can say that the bound is done between TRANSP interfaces, because bound is done after tloc-ext cfg is added, wright?

discussion.content: It should be C , Before applying Tloc-extension , ge 0/2.101 is a service port , The port-type will be changing after applying the command
Answer is D. but sub interface IP address is wrong. 10.1.100.0/24 is the Network address and cannot be used.
Shoul be D because both interface are in VPN-0 thai is transport2transport
I agree with D. Transport - Transport

When two vEdge routers are collocated at a site that has only one WAN circuit, you can configure the vEdge router that is not connected to the circuit to be able to establish WAN transport tunnels through the other router's TLOCs. In this way, you extend the WAN transport VPN so that both routers can establish tunnel interfaces, and hence can establish independent TLOCs, in the overlay network.

i really think is transport - ttransport

I think the answer is C. 

Cisco/Viptela documentation states, "A port type of "transport" indicates that the interface is configured as a tunnel interface, and a port type of "service" indicates that the interface is not configured as a tunnel interface and can be used for data plane traffic." 

Can be found at https://sdwan-https://sdwan-docs.cisco.com/Product_Documentation/Software_Features/SD-WAN_Release_16.2/02System_and_Interfaces/06Configuring_Network_Interfaces#:~:text=In%20this%20output%2C%20a%20port,used%20for%20data%20plane%20traffic.

comments.content: tlocs and tloc-extensions are always in the transport VPN (VPN0) any VPN different to VPN0 is service. . transport - transport. read how to configure tloc extensions.

discussion.content: Don't know how you figured it had anything to do with a service... but this is transport related. D is the only correct option here.

Answer is D! Look at both sides of the connection in the link below, they are BOTH in VPN 0 - the transport VPN: 
https://sdwan-docs.cisco.com/Product_Documentation/Software_Features/SD-WAN_Release_16.2/02System_and_Interfaces/06Configuring_Network_Interfaces
WAN edge router will perform NAT on the traffic from the TLOC-extended interface, so i agree it should be C, since source traffic will come from same service IP.
C is the correct one, port type on the interface extending the TLOC is "service"

discussion.content:
yes B is the right answer
sdwan 
nterface interface-name 
tunnel-interface 
 tloc-extension-gre-to extended-interface-ip-address

B is correct - the rest aren't valid commands:

vedge(config-vpn-0)# int g0/0
vedge(config-interface-g0/0)# gre-interface
------------------------------^
syntax error: unknown command
vedge(config-interface-g0/0)# extended-interface
------------------------------^
syntax error: unknown command
vedge(config-interface-g0/0)# tloc-interface
------------------------------^
syntax error: unknown command
vedge(config-interface-g0/0)# tunnel-interface
vedge(config-tunnel-interface)#
B is the correct answer
B is correct
it should be B
Bis correct

They worded the question badly. They ask which config is used to extend TLOC to another router. Worded that way, no answer is correct. Option B is the only answer without fake syntax, so it must be correct. But option B is not the config on the router that is extending the TLOC. It is the config on the other router, that the TLOC is being extended to. Still, the other answers are wrong on either router because they have fake syntax.

Correct B

vManage Feature Template
For Cisco IOS XE routers only:

Configuration ► Templates ► VPN Interface Ethernet

Command Hierarchy
sdwan
 interface interface-name
 tunnel-interface
 tloc-extension-gre-to extended-interface-ip-address

Yes B is correct answer
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/routers/sd-wan/220333-configure-layer-3-tloc-extension.html

B is correct : Configure a tunnel interface over which to run TLOC extensions (on IOS XE routers only). TLOC extensions allow you to extend a TLOC, over a GRE tunnel, to another router in the branch.

sdwan
 interface interface-name
 tunnel-interface
 tloc-extension-gre-to extended-interface-ip-address

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/command/sdwan-cr-book/config-cmd.html#r_tloc_extension_gre_to_11940.xml
B is the right one

Correct answer is B.

cEdge-4(config)# sdwan
cEdge-4(config-sdwan)# interface GigabitEthernet2
cEdge-4(config-interface-GigabitEthernet2)# tunnel-interface
cEdge-4(config-tunnel-interface)# tloc-extension-gre-to
correct answer is B
B is correct
I think tunnel-interface is the only command possible, which easily eliminates other options. So it's B.

B. Correct
Link: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/command/sdwan-cr-book/sdwan-cr-book_chapter_010.html#wp2314758100

sdwan interface tloc-extension-gre-to—Configure a tunnel interface over which to run TLOC extensions (on IOS XE routers only). TLOC extensions allow you to extend a TLOC, over a GRE tunnel, to another router in the branch.


sdwan interface tloc-extension-gre-from —Configure an interface as an extended interface, to channel TLOC traffic from a source branch router to the local WAN interface (on IOS XE routers only).
Also agree with B
tunnel-interface is the correct command for this one, B is correct.
